Fun fact Nile:

The mammary glands are highly modified apocrine sweat glands. Apocrine sweat glands are found in "stinky" areas of the human body like the arm pits, crotch, and anal area. They secrete an oily type of sweat.

So, milk is a form of specialized sweat, and the mammary glands are specialized sweat glands. Yum. I don't feel bad that I'm lactose intolerant. Soy milk > cow sweat. ;) Hahaha

I have some issues with you naming that a micelle. By definition, a micelle is thermodynamically stable. You can't have micelles in a dispersion/emulsion. A dispersion is kinetically, not thermodynamically, stable. The two are contradictory. Furthermore, micelles form a single phase, which is clearly not the case of milk. Duncan J Shaw's book, Intro to Colloid and Surface science, has more information.

How about some biochemistry experiments on your channel? Isolation of lysozyme by ion exchange chromatography is a really cool experiment to do. You can isolate it from eggs by diluting the egg white in a basic buffer and then let it run through a column stuffed with carboxy methyl cellulose. In a pH of about 10 or 11 (?) the lysozyme still contains positive charges, while nearly all the other hydrogens have dissociated from the other proteins which gives them more negative charges. After a few wash steps you can elute the lysozyme by adding a buffer with a lower pH (phosphate buffered saline). The presence of lysozyme can be shown by adding your fractions to a medium containing bacteria. When the medium clears up, lysozyme was present and destroyed the bacterial cell walls.
